description: From Middle French indispensable, from Medieval Latin indispensābilis, corresponding to in- +‎ dispensable.

adjectives.description: indispensable (comparative more indispensable, superlative most indispensable)

entries.meaning: (ecclesiastical, obsolete) Not admitting ecclesiastical dispensation; not subject to release or exemption; that cannot be allowed by bending the canonical rules. [16th–17th c.]
(of duties, rules etc.) Unbendable, that cannot be set aside or ignored. [from 17th c.]
Absolutely necessary or requisite; that one cannot do without. [from 17th c.]
examples: An indispensable component of a heart-healthy diet.

entries.meaning: A thing that is not dispensable; a necessity. [from 17th c.]
(in the plural, colloquial, dated) Trousers. [from 19th c.]
